results.title: No man's land = Nikogarsnja zemlja
results.creator_credit: Danis Tanovic, Cedomir Kolar, Frederique Dumas-Zajdela, Marc Baschet, Casablanca, Fabrica Films, Man's Films, Noe Productions and Studio Maj
results.brief_description: Written and directed by Danis Tanovic, “No man’s land” is an anti-war satire set in 1993, amid the Bosnian Serb war. A group of Bosnian soldiers advance toward Serbian lines in heavy fog; when day breaks they are clearly visible and massacred with the exception of Chiki, who runs to the nearest trench. When the Serbian troop responsible decide to investigate the outcome, only Nino, a novice soldier, survives the mission, and is now trapped in the same trench as Chiki. As the two men trade insults, the power shifts continuously between them and their situation is further complicated by the fact that Chiki has laid a tripped mine under the body of a Serbian soldier, Cera, who as it turns out, is still alive. A solution of kinds presents itself when the United Nations Peacekeeping force intervenes attempting to diffuse the standoff. When an English journalist cottons on to the ensuing drama, she seeks to attain a scoop for the network, which involves deal making and subterfuge. The tragedy of the war, and misfortune of these unfortunate three - a powerful allegory for the state of warfare - is underpinned by a bitterly absurd humour that permeates this thought-provoking and intelligent film that ponders the corruptibility of the UN, journalistic ethics and the futility of combat.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Danis Tanovic, Cedomir Kolar, Frederique Dumas-Zajdela, Marc Baschet, Casablanca, Fabrica Films, Man’s Films, Noe Productions and Studio Maj

results.title: The Hidden half = Nimeh-ye penhan [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Tahmineh Milani, Mohammad Nikbin, Arta Film and Iranian Film Society
results.brief_description: The dutiful wife of an Iranian judge uses her husband’s impending case of a woman facing execution for an unspecified crime to reveal the truth of her past revolutionary activities and to illustrate that the stories of people must be heard before passing judgement. Using the device of a diary and an extended flashback, Fereshteh (Niki Karima, Best Actress, Cairo International Film Festival) explains how her life changed drastically when she went to university, joined the Communist party, then fell in love with a married man. Feminist director Tahmineh Milani was imprisoned by the Islamic Revolutionary Court following the film’s release and is on parole; the film was also pulled from Tehran screens after a month but later returned. Melodramatic at times, the film’s history overshadows its content yet still manages to convey the oppression of Iranian women under an Islamic regime in pre and post revolutionary Iran. In Farsi with English subtitles. Please note: the white subtitles are sometimes hard to read on screen.

results.title: Two women = Do zan [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Tahmineh Milani, Arman Film and Arta Film
results.brief_description: Two women, Fereshteh (Niki Karimi) and Roya (Marila Zare’i) become friends while studying at Tehran University. There’s a cloud of doubt over whether the university will stay open however, there’s rioting, and Fereshteh fears her future plans to become educated and enlightened will not eventuate. One day she is approached by a girl at university who wants to introduce her to Ahmad, a potential husband, she’s also being harassed by a man who follows her around campus and insists he is in love with her. One day the man sees her with her cousin and, believing him to be her lover, throws acid on him. Fereshteh is unfairly blamed for the incident and her father demands she leave university and return home. An unfortunate accident removes her harasser when he is sent to jail, but Fereshteh is held to blame also and is bailed out by Ahmad, her life and family honour indebted to him due to his financial assistance. Milani’s fifth film is an accomplished piece about a woman stifled in her attempt at liberation by a trinity involving her father, her husband, and a stranger. In Farsi with English subtitles.

results.title: A Time for drunken horses = Zamani baraye masti asbha [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Bahman Ghobadi and Bahman Ghobadi Films
results.brief_description: Written and directed by Bahman Ghobadi “A Time for drunken horses” is an Iranian film set amid the mountainous border of Iran and Iraq. Ayoub (Ayoub Ahmadi) is a twelve-year-old Kurdish boy who is burdened with the economic responsibility of providing for his family. He has four bothers and sisters, one of whom is severely disabled. To eek out a living in the harsh landscape where his family live, Ayoub joins his uncle in a dangerous trade - taking pack mules loaded with truck tyres across the Iranian border to Iraq. The work is fraught with perils as the road is treacherous, bandits roam the terrain and rough weather impedes the journey. Once at the border Ayoub and his uncle ply their meagre goods, along with numerous others, for a pittance. Ayoub’s brother Madi is in need of a life saving operation that is prohibitively expensive for the impoverished family. Ayoub works against all the hazards to raise the necessary money. “A Time for drunken horses” has the feel and look of a documentary, one that expresses poignantly the trials of a valiant and resourceful child and his destitute people. In Farsi with English subtitles.

results.title: The Circle = Dayereh = Il Cerchio [Widescreen] [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Jafar Panahi, Jafar Panahi Film Productions, Lumière & Co. and Mikado Film Srl (Rome)
results.brief_description: From Iranian filmmaker Jafar Panahi (The White balloon), comes “The Circle” a tale of female oppression in modern day Iran. “The Circle” opens in a hospital maternity ward where a woman has just given birth. Her mother is horrified by the catastrophic outcome - its a girl. She had been assured (via ultrasound) that it would be a boy and laments the fact that a divorce will ensue and her daughter will be shamed. This opening sequence reflects the status of women in Iran, as unwanted, second-class citizens without rights or a voice in society. “The Circle” tells the stories of several women in a city over the course of one day and night. Simple acts of buying a bus ticket or smoking a cigarette in public are denied to women and are punishable by law. The women of the film, in constant danger of imprisonment and harassment, are shunned by their families and seek refuge with each other. Panahi adopts a documentary style for this feature film, as street noise fills the soundtrack and the camera follows the characters around, almost hounding them. “The Circle” was banned in Iran due to its controversial subject matter. In Farsi with English subtitles. (Awards: Winner of the Golden Lion, Best Film at the 2000 Venice Film Festival)

results.title: Daybill for the American release of Jedda
results.credit_line: Courtesy the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia.
results.brief_description: Jedda represented a lot of historic firsts for the Australian moving image, not just in the story it was telling but how that story was told. The first fully funded Australian narrative feature to be shot in colour in the country, it used a colour process known as the Belgian Gevacolor so it was possible to shoot on location among the Australian landscape.

results.title: Scott of the Antarctic
results.creator_credit: Charles Frend, Sir Michael Balcon and Rank Film Productions
results.brief_description: Saga of the ill fated 1912 expedition led by Captain Robert Scott which aimed to be the first to reach the South Pole. Features John Mills, James Robertson Justice and Kenneth Moore.

results.title: Teacher and technology
results.creator_credit: Milton Ingerson, South Australian Film Corporation and U-Tel
results.brief_description: Aims to promote technology awarness in teachers. Changes in needs and methods have led to a greater use of technology in the classroom, especially for self-paced learning. The practical applications of equipment are discussed. Children from four South Australian primary schools participated in the production. Essentially a promotion of the South Australian Educational Technology Centre. It emphasizes the need to teach using 1980s technology. Hardware covered includes over-head projectors, computers, video, film.

results.title: Bugsy Malone
results.creator_credit: Allan Parker, Alan Marshall, David Puttnam and Goodtimes Enterprises
results.brief_description: A mad gangster musical set in the New York of the 1920s, a world of would-be hoodlums, show girls and dreamers. But there are no adults, only children. Bugsy, Blousey, Tallulah, Fat Sam, Fizzy, Leroy and Loney are some of the characters involved in a bitter gang war for possession of the dreaded “spurge gun”. Stars a very young Jodie Foster.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Allan Parker, Alan Marshall, David Puttnam and Goodtimes Enterprises

results.title: Jedda
results.brief_description: Australia’s first colour feature and Chauvel’s last film, ‘Jedda’ is arguably the first Australian film to take the emotional lives of Aboriginal people seriously.
results.description: ‘Jedda’, Charles Chauvel’s last feature film and Australia’s first in colour, is the story of a teenage Aboriginal girl who has been raised by a white woman, and finds herself drawn to Marbuck, a full-blooded Aborigine who comes to the station for work. The film falls readily into two halves. The first details Jedda’s upbringing and her emotional turmoil as to her identity, which is solved by Jedda herself, when the call of her blood leads her into the physical and psychological world of her people. The second half of the film, photographed in spectacular Central Australian locations, concentrates on the tension of the chase in which Marbuck and Jedda are pursued by the men from Jedda’s station. Cast includes Ngarla Kunoth as Jedda, Robert Tudawali as Marbuck, Betty Suttor, Paul Reynall, George Simpson-Lytle, Tas Fitzer, Wason Byers, Willie Farrar, Margaret Dingle. Also available on DVD [319218].
